title: Why were the rulers of ancient Egypt Greek? - Quora

response.answer_text: To answer this question lets start with “when” Egypt was because there were 3 different periods, there were some intermediate periods between the main periods as well. These were Old Kingdom Egypt from 2,700–2,200 B.C.E., Middle Kingdom Egypt from 2,050–1,800 B.C.E., and Egypt from 1,550–1,100 B.C.E. Ancient Egypt was defined by these three periods until it was conquered by the Greeks in 332 BC by the Greeks under Alexander the Great, who I might add also conquered the Greeks since they were individual tribes before he did so. Before digging into the Greeks take over of the Egyptians, it is worth noting that Egypt was conquered by other people's before the Greeks did by the Nubians, the Assyrians, the Persians, and others. These people didn't change much of Egyptian culture like the Greeks did. The Late Period of Ancient Egyptian history, or the New Kingdom, came to an end in 332 BC when Egypt was conquered by the Greeks under Alexander the Great who also conquered Greece, much of the Middle East, and even India and formed their own dynasty, the Ptolemaic Dynasty after his child Ptolemy in 305 B.C.E., ruling for nearly 300 years until 30 B.C.E. He, given how vain he was isn't surprising, named his capital Alexandria. They say Ancient Egypt ended around Ptolemy's reign due to Incorporation of Greek into Egyptian culture. It did boost Alexandria due to trade between Asia, Africa, and Europe and even became the center of Greek culture and education with The Library of Alexandria. After Ptolemy III died, the dynasty was weakened by rebellion and corruption and eventually fell to the Romans as they gained power in the Mediterranean. In 30 BC the Rmans took control and ruled for over 600 years until around 640 AD.
